Transcript:
Ira: So any big changes in your tax return 
this year?

Harley: You don't read the newspaper much, do 
you?
Ira: Not much.

Harley: Okay, well, I started out the year 
making 50 cents a day because I was in prison, and I ended the year married-- 
which is good, right?-- Making six figures as a CEO.
Ira: Oh, all right. Gus?

Gus: Nope, everything's easy for me. Although 
next year might be a problem because I was legally dead, partially, briefly. Do 
I get a tax break for that?
Ira: I'll have to look that one up.

Harley: Anyway, I don't think these um-- 
honey-- these receipts really tell the story of what kind of a year we also 
have. I don't think they also tell you how good it feels to be normal again.
Gus: Save all of these, though, you know.
Harley: You okay?
Gus: What are we talking about?
Ira: Prison salary. You had quite a year.

Harley: Yes. I hope to you never have a year 
like that ever again.

Ira: Look at it this way, now you can handle 
anything life throws you.

Harley: Somehow it doesn't make me feel 
better. Can we just go back to tax talk? There is stuff everywhere, sweetie.
Mallet: Hey, I know you're upset, and that's understandable.
Frank: Hey little brother.
Coop: Hey.
Frank: Have you seen Harley?
Coop: No. It's not my day to watch her.

Frank: That's a good thing because you're too 
busy watching Ava.
Coop: Okay.

Frank: Get over here. What are you doing 
here? Get in there and sweep her off her feet.

Coop: "Sweep her off her feet." Is that 
something you would say, Frank?

Frank: Listen, if you don't like her, yeah, 
I'd love to sweep her off of her feet.
Coop: Okay. All right, all right.

Frank: But you know what? Taking another 
man's woman is not exactly my style.

Coop: Wow. Is there something we need to talk 
about?

Frank: No. I just need to talk to Harley, is 
what I need to do. And being that she's not here, I'm out of here. Now, Henry, 
go in there and get the girl.
Coop: Okay. Thank you, thank you.

Josh: Now what did that poor rug ever do to you, unless of course you're 
pretending that it's somebody else. Maybe-- I don't know-- Jeffrey.

Cassie: How about you and Reva for being such 
idiots yesterday. I can't even believe you went through with that divorce.

Josh: Yes, we did. But then later on we 
changed our minds and we tore up the paperwork!
Cassie: You did?
Josh: Yeah.
Cassie: Really?
Josh: Yeah.
Cassie: Josh, that is great news!
Josh: I'm still your brother- in-law.

Cassie: I'm so happy for you. Did I tell you 
or did I tell you?
Josh: You told me.
Cassie: Where's Reva? We've got to celebrate.

Josh: Actually, she went to Paris to be with 
Marah. That's a good thing, though. She didn't want to disappoint her, change 
her plans, you know. And she wanted to give her the good news. But Reva can't 
wait to get back and I can't wait to have her back. So, you're going to have to 
find somebody else to beat the crap out of. Maybe Jonathan.

Cassie: No. I'm turning over a new leaf. I 
told Tammy that I'm going to keep my opinions to myself and I'm going to let her 
make her own decisions, right or wrong. And I am really going to try to stick to 
that.
Josh: Okay.
Tammy: Mom? Hi, Uncle Josh.
Josh: Hey, Tammy.
Cassie: Hi, honey. I'm so glad to see you.

Tammy: Oh. I'm going to hang on to that for a 
second, because you might not feel that way after I ask you this question.
Cassie: Why, what are you going to ask me?

Tammy: Um... did you really mean what you 
said about supporting me and Jonathan?
Cassie: Support?
Tammy: How about tolerate?
Cassie: Better.

Tammy: Good, because I'm about to put you to 
the test. Isn't it fun being a mom?
Tammy: Uh-huh.
Lizzie: I will take one of those and a tequila chaser, please.
Jonathan: How about a soda?
Lizzie: What's with this chaperone thing?

Jonathan: I just don't need you getting 
sloppy drunk around here.

Lizzie: Why, are you afraid you won't able to 
control yourself?

Jonathan: What? I told you not to come back 
here.
Lizzie: What are you so worried about?

Jonathan: You left this in my bed, Lizzie. 
Tammy found it, okay?

Lizzie: All right. What was I supposed to 
say? Wait a minute, what was Tammy doing in your bed?
Jonathan: Come on.
Lizzie: No.
Jonathan: Goodbye.

Lizzie: Please tell me you didn't taker back? 
What about making her beg? What about the restraining order she had against you.

Jonathan: We settled out of court. 
Everything's fine now. Everything is under control.
Lizzie: Everything except for me.
Harley: What are you doing?

Gus: This is stale. The place is going 
downhill.
Harley: Uh-huh.

Gus: I just needed to stretch my leg. Where 
did Ira go?

Harley: I told him that we were going to file 
an extension if that's okay.
Gus: "Ira."
Harley: Ira, our accountant.
Gus: I'm okay with an extension.

Harley: Good. I didn't think we should rush 
into doing our taxes, if we really didn't have to, especially since you're not 
feeling so hot.
Gus: No. I feel good.

Harley: Feel good? Is that why you're still 
popping these?

Dinah: I want you to be honest with me, okay? Am I widely insecure to be ticked 
off at this entire thing?

Mallet: Well, let's see. Well, we've got a 
whole article here, and it's mostly about your father's legacy, and about 
Blake's run for mayor. And it finishes up with everything about-- talks about 
the kids. So you have a whole article and it's not even about you and you're not 
even mentioned. So, yeah, I would be a little annoyed.

Dinah: Are you kidding me? I wasn’t even 
talking about this article. I was talking about this one on page six. This is 
unbelievable! No matter what I do, I'm invisible, an after-thought.

Mallet: Well, you make my front page 
headline.

Dinah: I think that I'm going nuts. I'm at 
the headline, but what about the other night. The other night when you said 
"extra, extra," you now. "Mallet and his ex-wife, they do it."

Mallet: That was history. All right. Very 
much history. Not a headline.

Dinah: You're going to tell me that your ego 
doesn't love having two women who want you.

Mallet: Well there's one woman I don't want, 
and there is one that is more than I can handle.

Dinah: Yes, you're right, detective. I am 
more than you can handle.
Ava: Hey, what are you doing? Stop!
Coop: If you want to-- It's quitting time.

Ava: I don't know who's watch you're looking 
at, but I'm still working.

Coop: Well, I said so because I'm the boss's 
son. Come on, let's go out and celebrate. What do you say?
Ava: Celebrate what?

Coop: Whatever. Do we need a reason to 
celebrate?
Ava: If I'm going to be losing tips, yeah.

Coop: Fine, fine. Let's go out and celebrate 
that I did an amazing job of plastering the wall between our rooms, how about 
that? You like that, don't you?

Ava: Yeah, you mean the whole you punched 
through the wall? Yeah. I'm still not convinced you didn't do that on purpose.

Coop: Well, I guess that would just make the 
me the world's biggest Peeping Tom now, wouldn't it?
Ava: You want to be the best?

Coop: Oh. That is a good point. Anyways, 
look. You, my dear, look pretty ravishing in the whole little facial mask thing 
you had going on.
Ava: Oh, shut-- shut up! Stop it.

Coop: It was a good look for you; I liked it. 
Come on, let's just go out-- hey, it was a good look for you. Let's just have 
some fun. Come on, lighten up a little bit. We had fun fixing the wall, didn't 
we? Yes?

Ava: Yes. We had a lot of fun. We did. You 
know, speaking of walls, there is something to be said for walls. You can't get 
hurt through walls. And you can't get heartbroken when a certain guy goes back 
to a certain girl again.

Coop: Ava, please. Come here, look at me. 
That's not going to happen, all right? Lizzie and I are done.
Ava: Can I have your solemn vow on that?
Coop: My solemn vow?
Ava: Yes.

Coop: Yes, you can. And I will cross my heart 
with it, too.

Jonathan: Why do I get the feeling you can't let go of the one night we spent 
together.
Lizzie: Oh, please.

Jonathan: You're here all of the time; you're 
lonely.

Lizzie: Okay, don't flatter yourself. I'm 
fine.
Jonathan: Yeah, you look fine.

Lizzie: I just think it's a little hilarious 
and a little pathetic that all of a sudden you and Tammy think you can just work 
it out. Did you wake up a new respectable human being? Ooh, wait, wait. Now, 
Tammy has a mom who doesn't hate you.

Jonathan: ( Laughs ) Yeah, you're just pissy 
because I'm back with Tammy and Coop won't take you back.

Lizzie: He will soon. I stole Ava's room key 
from Buzz. I'm going to break in and look around--
Jonathan: Bad idea.
Lizzie: How can you say that?

Jonathan: Because I know! Digging up dirt on 
Ava's the worst thing you can do.

Lizzie: Well, listen to you, the relationship 
expert.

Jonathan: No. But I'm doing a lot better than 
you are. Look, if you want to get Coop back, the way to get him back is not to 
get rid of Ava. The way to get him back is to get rid of Coop.
Cassie: You want me to invite Jonathan to dinner?

Tammy: Close your mouth. Flies. It's no big 
deal. It can just be a normal family dinner. We sit around, we talk, we eat, we 
laugh. Eat some more and talk. No fights, no fires, and no physical violence of 
any kind.

Cassie: Well, you know, that sounds 
refreshing, when do you want to do this?
Tammy: Tonight?
Josh: ( Laughs )
Tammy: What, why not?

Josh: Tammy, sometimes people like a little 
thing called notice.

Tammy: Why, so she can agonize over it and 
turn it into some huge deal which it doesn't need to be? You said you would 
respect my decision to be with Jonathan, Mom.
Cassie: I did.
Tammy: You said you'd try.

Cassie: And I will, I will. And what better 
way than to plunge right in with a home-cooked meal. So, is Jonathan allergic to 
anything? I mean, other than me?

Tammy: Thank you. Thank you. Oh, you're the 
best.

Josh: I just want to say that I think the two 
of you handled this very nicely. I'll see you; have fun tonight.

Cassie: No, no, no. I need reinforcements, 
and you've got to eat dinner.
Josh: That's a bad idea, Cassie.
Cassie: I think you're a coward.

Josh: I'm not a coward; I just think I would 
hurt more than I would help, and Jonathan doesn't like me a whole lot these 
days.

Tammy: No, that is not true, Uncle Josh. 
Jonathan likes you.
Josh: What?

Tammy: Okay, okay. Well, he respects you. 
Which is better. Mom's right, you should be here. Besides, it would help to have 
another guy, and you're a guy.
Josh: I appreciate you pointing that out.
Tammy: Don't make me beg.

Josh: Okay, all right, I guess I can spare 
the evening.

Cassie: Then we're set. I'll just see what's 
in the freezer, get cooking. What time is Jonathan coming over?
Tammy: I don't know, I haven't asked him yet.
Cassie: This is going to be super.
Josh: ( Laughs )
Cassie: Fun, fun, fun.

Lizzie: Get rid of Coop? Are you nuts? That is the last thing I would want to 
do.
Jonathan: You're not listening.

Lizzie: Because you're not making any sense. 
( Cell phone rings )
Jonathan: Hello.
Tammy: Hey. What are you doing right now?
Jonathan: Nothing much. Why?

Tammy: Because I have an offer that you 
cannot refuse.

Jonathan: Dinner tonight? With your mom and 
Joshua, what are you looking for bloodshed?
Lizzie: ( Laughs )
Tammy: Jonathan, where are you?

Jonathan: I'm at Outskirts. There are some 
really obnoxious people here. Your mom wanting me to come over is not the same 
as playing musical chairs.

Tammy: Well, I didn't think that would be 
part of it. It's just dinner, and she's into it. So how about you?

Jonathan: I don't know. The last family event 
I went to turned into wrestle mania 20.

Tammy: Not this time. This is different. This 
is the start of us being normal again.
Jonathan: Normal?
Lizzie: Ooh, can I come?

Jonathan: Look, if it's that important to 
you, okay. But let's get one thing straight: I am done auditioning to your 
family. If anything, they have something to prove to me now.
Tammy: Well, me, too.
Jonathan: Maybe.

Tammy: Well, how can I prove myself if you're 
not here?
Jonathan: What time?
Tammy: Five, or whenever you can make it.
Jonathan: Should I bring brownies?

Lizzie: Oh, dinner with the family, it's so 
sweet.

Jonathan: Well, me and Tammy are going to try 
to be more normal. It's going to help us really stick.

Lizzie: Well, Coop and I are going to stick, 
too.

Jonathan: Uh-huh. Only if you take my advice 
and get him the hell out of dodge.
Lizzie: Dodge? What are you talking about?
Jonathan: You know what, forget it?
Lizzie: Forget what?
Jonathan: You're smart. You figure it out.

Coop: Wow, I guess the walls are back up, aren't they? All plastered and 
painted, huh?

Ava: No. It's just that you and Lizzie just 
broke up. I just want to take things slow, that's all.

Coop: Well, um, if that's the case, well, 
maybe we should just cancel the plans for tonight and you should just put this

here, okay? I just want to spend time with you. Is that so wrong? Just you and

Ava: Why?
Coop: You really don't know?
Ava: No. Tell me.

Coop: Okay. All right, fine, you want to hear 
it? Here it is: Because you're fine and you're funny, and you're witty and 
you're smart.
Ava: And cute.

Coop: Yes, I was getting to there. You're 
cute, too. And every time--
Ava: Sometimes.

Coop: No, all the time. Every time I'm with 
you, I want to tell you everything, but like now, I can't even get a complete

last year. Unfortunately I had to turn it down. Again? No, ah-- are you serious? 
Another shot at Oxford?
Gus: I don't know how those got there.
Harley: I saw you take one.

Gus: I just had one. Because my leg, the 
weather-- you know. Listen, all I need is an aspirin, honestly, and I don't have 
an aspirin. It's no big deal.
Harley: Then why lie to me about it?

Gus: Did I? I just didn't want you to worry 
about it, that's all. I know you're such a worry wart.

Harley: Honey, if you're leg hurts, go to a 
doctor. Talk to the doctor about what's wrong with your leg. They can make it

Gus: All right, listen. You take those, you 
can have those, okay. You take them, do-- flush them down the toilet because all

I'll be happy with that. That's all I need.

Harley: Just talk to Rick, he is a good guy. 
Just talk to him.
Gus: Rick, okay.
Harley: Because you don't want to talk to me.
Gus: I am. That's cool. I'm good with that.

Harley: Hey! There you are, my right arm, I 
would be lost without you, sweetie.
Dinah: Oh.
Mallet: Good?

Cassie: Well, look at you, I thought this was supposed to be a normal, casual, 
everyday dinner.

Tammy: I could still look good, can't I? ( 
Knock on the door ) Hey, I'm so glad you're here.
Jonathan: You're all dressed up.
Josh: Hello, Jonathan.

Jonathan: Joshua, Cassie. Here, these are for 
you.
Cassie: Almost a six-pack.

Jonathan: Yeah, I pounded one on the way

Cassie: That's really thoughtful, thank you. 
This is perfect. Actually, it will go with what we're having. Chili, I hope you

Jonathan: Yeah, sure.

Cassie: Good. Then why don't we go into the

Tammy: Yeah. This is good, right?
Cassie: Yeah.
Jonathan: Oh, yeah.
Tammy: Good.

Marcy Rylan, "Inside The 
Light."

I get very nervous for interviews, 
I have to warn you guys. I am really excited about playing Lizzie, which is 
really fun. I grew up in central Pennsylvania, country girl. Where I grew up, 
people don't become actors. It's not in the list of things, a high school 
moment. I thought I could do this for the rest of my life. And I did.

See Lizzie, Wednesday, April 19th, 
"Inside The Light."

Tammy: This guy comes into Outskirts and is going to get us a ticket to the 
concert.
Cassie: That's great.

Tammy: He's doing Jonathan a favor because he 
helped him when his car broke down.
Cassie: That's great.

Jonathan: Yeah, a friend to every drunk in 
town, including your brother. Not that I think he is drinking now, to my

mistakes of his own, and that's why he doesn't judge people.

Cassie: Do you enjoy owning a bar? I know it 
was kind of forced on you.
Tammy: He's great at it.

Cassie: But is it something you want to do 
long-term? Or are there other things you want to do?

Jonathan: No. I never thought I would ever be 
this settled down.
Cassie: You mean at this age?

Jonathan: No. I mean, owning something and 
being responsible, that was never my thing.
Josh: Really, you?

Cassie: Some people take longer to find 
themselves.

Josh: I can certainly relate to that. I was 
one of those people.

Cassie: Oh, come on. I'm sure you always knew 
where were you headed and had your feet planted firmly on the ground.

Josh: No, that's not true. I did a lot of 
things growing up and made a lot of people angry at me, including my father.
Cassie: Really?
Josh: Mm-hmm.
Cassie: I never knew that about you?

Jonathan: You always had his millions to fall 
back on if you screwed up.

Josh: That was a blessing and a curse. 
Everything comes with a price, including money.

Cassie: That's right, everything does. I 
think we all make our mistakes. I think we all have to pay our dues one way or

happy. I'm grateful tonight that we're all feeling pretty happy, right?
Tammy: Right.

Cassie: And we have what matters most right

Josh: Nothing, Cassie. You couldn't have been 
nicer.

Tammy: Excuse me. Jonathan, it's not working, 
is it?

Coop: No, thank you, thank you very, very much. Good-bye. That was Oxford 
University.

Ava: I know. I know, about the writing 
fellowship. What did they say?

Coop: They said they received an anonymous 
grant, which means that this year there's going to be another writing

Ava: And you got it?

Coop: No, I didn't get it, but they said if I 
would reapply, that they would put me on the short list for it.

Ava: Well, you almost had it last year. Coop, 
that's so awesome!
Coop: I've got to think about this, Ava.

Ava: Think about what? Are you kidding me? I 
know how much you wanted this. You left it behind because of Lizzie. Come on, we 
really have something to celebrate. Let's go.
Coop: That's true.
Lizzie: Can I celebrate, too?
Ava: Lizzie, how did you know about Oxford?

Lizzie: Oxford? I was talking about Coop's 
birthday. What are you guys talking about?
Ava: It's your birthday today?
Lizzie: Tomorrow.
Ava: Why didn't you tell me?

Lizzie: Henry hates to make a big deal about 
his birthday.

Coop: Well, that depends. Sometimes I am 
really up for celebrating.

Lizzie: Is that what you guys are going to do 
tomorrow night?
Coop: Or tonight. Whatever you want.

Lizzie: Wow, you must really be a good 
influence on him, Ava. Maybe you can get him to accept this small gift.
Coop: Lizzie--

Lizzie: No, wait. It is nothing fancy. It's 
just something that I saw that I thought you would like. We're friends now. 
Friends remember each other's birthdays.
Ava: Open it.
Coop: Oh.

Lizzie: You're always jotting down ideas for 
stories, so I thought--

Coop: Lizzie, this is beautiful. This is... 
this is... thank you.
Ava: You can take it to Oxford.
Coop: If I go.
Ava: When you go.

Lizzie: Oxford again, what are you guys 
talking about?

Ava: He just got a call from Oxford saying 
they have another writing fellowship, and Coop is going to get it.
Coop: That's a little optimistic--

Lizzie: Really? That's great. I'm so happy 
for you.

Coop: It is not definite, and there are tests 
I have to take and writings and samples.

Lizzie: Please. They gave it to you before, 
and they're going to give it to him again.
Ava: Exactly.
Lizzie: You are so sweet to be so supportive.
Ava: Why wouldn't I be?

Lizzie: I don't know, I guess if I was still 
his girlfriend, I'd probably be worried that he'd go off and follow up with one 
of those classy, brilliant Oxford girls and never come home. But clearly you 
must be more secure than I am.
Ava: Clearly.
Harley: Thank you. So tell me about last night. Any problems?
Dinah: No problems. None.

Harley: Good. Because the people are raving 
what a great party it was, the coverage by the press is amazing, and we raised 
tons of money...
Dinah: We did a good job. All of us did.

Harley: Yeah. And I'm sorry I didn't give you 
a heads-up about the speech. That was really a last-minute decision because I 
felt like I wasn't going to be there, but I should be there in some small way to 
show people that I'm in charge, that somebody is in charge. Especially with 
Alan-Michael.

Dinah: Well, you know what, people know that 
you're in charge. They do, especially now.
Harley: You mad at me?
Dinah: About what?

Harley: Okay. This is me promising you for 
the record that the next time there's some big event at Spaulding, come hell or 
high water, I will be there.

Dinah: Well, good. That's what I wanted to 
hear. So, Gus, he looks a little stronger. The pills aren't an issue anymore?

Harley: No. We talked. He's going cold 
turkey.
Gus: Stop.

Mallet: Hey. I've got to go. I'll call you. 
Bye, everybody.
Gus: See ya.

Dinah: You know, I think I'm going to go 
ahead and go to my appointment.
Mallet: What, I thought we were hanging out?

Dinah: Honey, I'm sorry, I didn't tell you. I 
will be back a little later. All right?
Mallet: Okay.

Tammy: It's not right, is it? Okay, so you don't like this, not yet. I just 
wanted to prove that I love you, that I can have you and I can have my family, 
too.
Jonathan: It's just weird.

Tammy: And you're not ready to trust that. I 
can't say I blame you. You think I'm pushing.
Jonathan: No, it wasn't that.
Tammy: What?

Jonathan: No, it wasn't that, whatever, 
dinner, being with your mom, she was like really talking to me, and she would 
look me in the eyes. I don't know. I know we took a few shots at each other, but 
it felt kind of harmless. I guess, like when a real family takes shots at each 
other. I don't know.
Tammy: So you liked it?

Jonathan: Yeah, I mean... I mean not to do 
every night, but sometimes, yeah.
Tammy: So why did you come out here?

Jonathan: I don't know. I'm kind of freaked 
out. But I had an okay time.
Tammy: Jonathan. Thank you. Hmmm, thank you.

Coop: This fellowship is not a done deal. And even if I were to get it, I 
wouldn't go over until the summer.

Lizzie: Please, those are details. The point 
is, Coop, your dream is going to come true.

Coop: Well, at least part of it. Is your 
passport ready?
Ava: Is my-- mine? Yeah, why.

Coop: Because you're going to need it if 
you're going to come with me.
Ava: Come with you...

Coop: To Oxford. Ava, listen, okay? You can 
get a waitress job over there just as easily as here, right?
Ava: Yeah.

Coop: And you can take classes, too. So when 
we're not taking classes and when you're not taking classes or working, we can 
travel. We can go to see Bath. We can go to Brighton. We could even go to 
London. And if my brother's around, we can even see him, too. Plus the easiest 
thing is... Paris is just so close, right next door.
Ava: Paris?
Coop: Yes. What do you think?
Lizzie: Coop, hi, wait.
Ava: What do I think?

Lizzie: That might not be workable. Ava needs 
to get a visa.

Coop: That's not a problem. I mean, we have 
plenty of time between now and then, but the only question is: Are you 
interested?

Ava: Am I interested? Are you kidding me? Oh, 
my gosh, Paris! Yes, of course.

Coop: That's answer enough. Okay, you know 
what? Let me just tell you, if I can find the guy who gave this anonymous grant, 
I don't know what I would do. I would probably give him a kiss or something like 
that at this point.
Ava: Okay.

Coop: Come on, I'll tell you what. Come here, 
I've got something to show you.
Ava: Okay. Oh, my God.
Lizzie: Her-- he'd give her a kiss.
Gus: Didn't we have a couple of dates. What happened?

Harley: Life happened. Commitments, 
obligations, taxes. All that mundane stuff that seems great to me now that my 
husband is back.
Mallet: Good, so, you're happy?
Harley: I'm very happy. You happy?
